body: Duplicate with #13222

Looks it is caused by `-Dmaven.test.skip=true`, since `shardingsphere-integration-agent-test-common` is a test-jar, it should be compiled and packaged, but it's ignored by `-Dmaven.test.skip=true`.

Use `-DskipTests` instead could solve it.

> I assume that shardingsphere disable autoCommit on all the connections to the backend databases. Since we have to control the transaction by ourself according to the different transactionType setting in the configuration, is it right ?

Yep, we need to control trx flow. Plus, I presume at this moment, we need to consider how to gracefully support XA transaction. I see @roodkcab did a lot of work on parsing and implementing XA SQL. Why isn't XA SQL supported so far? Actually, ShardingSpehre planned to hide the distributed transaction from users. Users do not need to be aware of the distributed transactions as if they are using one DBMS (Local trx). Imaging users take Proxy as a standalone DB, it's supposed that no distributed trx comes to their mind. That's why we haven't supported XA trx so far. We hope to hide and simplify the distributed transaction implementance from users. Only by calling non-distributed transactions simple API, users can achieve distributed trx. The key role during this process is ShardingSphere.

However, from distributed trx angle, It's fine to make ShardingSphere support XA API. But we need to consider how to make ShardingSphere responds to XA user API reasonably.

> Then I propose the following changes with TransactionBackendHandlerFactory

Honestly speaking, I am a little blurred of 
```java
No.61      return new TransactionBackendHandler(tclStatement, TransactionOperationType.BEGIN, backendConnection); 
```
I suppose this statement is to make ShardingSphere prepared for the next coming trx. Suppose the next coming command is a DML, e.g. `SELECT xxxx`, rather than the expected `begin trx`, what will happen? We still need implicitly **BEGIN** trx, right? (i.e., `return new TransactionBackendHandler(tclStatement, TransactionOperationType.BEGIN, backendConnection);`)

Appreciate your great providing. Therefore,

If `InTrx`, we need to commit whatever users request (`set auto_commit = false/true`). In contrast, if `NotInTrx`, we need to handle different situations.

> @tuichenchuxin Can you help check this issue? I remember that we have fixed this problem in the master branch.

Sorry, I want to ask what fix is? Now doesn't `INTERVAL` need to define `actual-data-nodes`?

> Yep, we need to control trx flow. Plus, I presume at this moment, we need to consider how to gracefully support XA transaction. I see @roodkcab did a lot of work on parsing and implementing XA SQL. Why isn't XA SQL supported so far? Actually, ShardingSpehre planned to hide the distributed transaction from users. Users do not need to be aware of the distributed transactions as if they are using one DBMS (Local trx). Imaging users take Proxy as a standalone DB, it's supposed that no distributed trx comes to their mind. That's why we haven't supported XA trx so far. We hope to hide and simplify the distributed transaction implementance from users. Only by calling non-distributed transactions simple API, users can achieve distributed trx. The key role during this process is ShardingSphere.

I see, it's really nice to support XA trx transparently. I don't think there's any easy way to support such feature, considering we have no context to know users' SQLs to be executed without calling ```XA``` statements explicitly.
 
> However, from distributed trx angle, It's fine to make ShardingSphere support XA API. But we need to consider how to make ShardingSphere responds to XA user API reasonably.

any suggestion is wellcome.

  `QUEUE_COUNT` int(11) DEFAULT '0',
  `LATEST_BUILD_ID` varchar(34) DEFAULT NULL,
  `LATEST_TASK_ID` varchar(34) DEFAULT NULL,
  `LATEST_START_USER` varchar(64) DEFAULT NULL,
  `LATEST_START_TIME` timestamp NULL DEFAULT NULL,
  `LATEST_END_TIME` timestamp NULL DEFAULT NULL,
  `LATEST_TASK_COUNT` int(11) DEFAULT NULL,
  `LATEST_TASK_NAME` varchar(128) DEFAULT NULL,
  `LATEST_STATUS` int(11) DEFAULT NULL,
  `BUILD_NUM_ALIAS` varchar(256) DEFAULT NULL,
  PRIMARY KEY (`PIPELINE_ID`),
  KEY `PRJOECT_ID` (`PROJECT_ID`,`PIPELINE_ID`)
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8;

**They all have the same sharding field projectId，the sharding rule is：**

fun getTableRuleConfiguration(
    tableName: String,
    specifyDataSourceName: String? = null
): ShardingTableRuleConfiguration? {
    // 生成实际节点规则
    val actualDataNodes = if (specifyDataSourceName != null) {
        "$specifyDataSourceName.$tableName"
    } else {
        "ds_\${0..1}.$tableName"
    }
    val tableRuleConfig = ShardingTableRuleConfiguration(tableName, actualDataNodes)
    tableRuleConfig.tableShardingStrategy = NoneShardingStrategyConfiguration()
    tableRuleConfig.databaseShardingStrategy =
        StandardShardingStrategyConfiguration(PROJECT_ID_FIELD, "bkProcessDatabaseShardingAlgorithm")
    return tableRuleConfig
}

Thank you for your answer.

Hi @roodkcab 

> I see, it's really nice to support XA trx transparently. I don't think there's any easy way to support such feature, considering we have no context to know users' SQLs to be executed without calling XA statements explicitly.

It's possible for ShardingSphere to know, as it needs to deal with users' SQL (parsing, routing and rewriting) and send them to DB. Therefore, if we find this logic SQL in one transaction will be executed in different DBs, then XA (or B.A.S.E) begins to work. Otherwise, this trx will become a local trx. From this perspective, it looks like we can provide users the local trx API but treat it as a XA internally. I am curious which case drives you to call XA API? Do you think the current transaction function of ShardingSphere can meet your needs? 

Hi @zhfeng 
I'd like to expand the distributed SQLs ShardingSphere faces,
First, the case you mentioned (One logic SQL has multiple actual SQLs) is certainly a kind of distributed transaction. Moreover, the following one is another case.
```sql
begin;
// This SQL is going to be executed on db0, db1
update t_order
// This SQL will be executed on db2, db3
update t_item
commit;
```

> And in term of XA support, I think the user would like to coordinate the database operation and others by the external Transaction Manager. For example, insert into db and send a message to MQ

I am interested in this case. Could you explain more? I mean, like a Java program, a XA can deal with different types of databases in the same trx? Does that mean redis also implement the XA API?

> Hi @roodkcab
> 
> > I see, it's really nice to support XA trx transparently. I don't think there's any easy way to support such feature, considering we have no context to know users' SQLs to be executed without calling XA statements explicitly.
> 
> It's possible for ShardingSphere to know, as it needs to deal with users' SQL (parsing, routing and rewriting) and send them to DB. Therefore, if we find this logic SQL in one transaction will be executed in different DBs, then XA (or B.A.S.E) begins to work. Otherwise, this trx will become a local trx. 

how does shardingsphere-proxy distinguish sqls on two different connections belong to one XA transaction ?

>From this perspective, it looks like we can provide users the local trx API but treat it as a XA internally. I am curious which case drives you to call XA API? Do you think the current transaction function of ShardingSphere can meet your needs?

It's actually some projects already use XA statements.

@tristaZero In your cases, all of db[0-3] are the same type of databases. I think when ```begin```, the shardingsphere could start a XA transaction by TransactionManger and all of the backend connection must be XADataSource, and then
```
update t_order // executed on db0, db1
```
XADataSource connect to db0, db1 can be enlisted (which means joining the XA transaction) automatically, this should be supported by HikariCP.

This same happens on ```update t_item```. And ```commit``` at last, it will commit all of the changes to 4 backend databases. I explain this in Shardingsphere XA mode.

And yeah, different types of database can support XA protocol.

Since both `db-discovery` and `readwrite-splitting` are dataSource enhance rules, `SingleTableRule` will aggregate data sources in reverse order during initialization. When the `readwrite-splitting` rule is processed, data sources in `db-discovery` will be parsed out, which result in aggregated pipeline cannot be connected.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10829171/138837476-45fe320d-3fe1-4307-8b4a-0f6dd2e3ce11.png)

According to rules of pipeline delivery, the result here should be logical data source of `db-discovery`, that is `pr_ds`. However, there are also problems with this logic. When routing, `readwrite-splitting` will route the `rd_rs` logical data source to `pr_ds`, and then pass it to `db-discovery` for routing, but `db-discovery `module does not have the capability of readwrite routing, so the result is still incorrect.

Considering that `db-discovery` has no readwrite routing capabilities, I think it’s better not to aggregate data sources for it. The data sources configured in `db-discovery` rules are directly passed to `readwrite-splitting` for use, so that the logic can be correct during routing.
as far as I know, redis does not support XA, but it support [transaction](https://redis.io/topics/transactions) to allow the execution of a group of commands in a single step.

> 3. Feature-distsql may need to use the objects in feature-core, but because of the dependency order, it cannot be imported conveniently.

Maybe we need to keep it with same reason to previous questions.
